raw_text:
Weak dollar hits Reuters
 
 Revenues at media group Reuters slipped 11% during 2004, mainly due to the weakness of the dollar, the group said.
 
 The company said it was optimistic about growth even as revenues slipped 11% from £3.24bn ($6.13bn) in 2003 to £2.89bn in 2004. Reuters beat profit forecasts, posting a 52% rise in profits for the year to £198m from the £130m seen a year earlier. Reuters also beat its savings target for 2004, delivering £234m of cuts. Under its three-year Fast Forward turnaround plan it had aimed to save £220m during the 12 months to 31 December.
 
 Reuters also managed to slow a decline in underlying revenues to 5.4% from 10.2% in 2003 and cut its debt back to £160m from £610m a year earlier. The news and financial data seller said the year had begun well, adding it expected "further gradual improvement" in the second quarter of the year after good January sales. It added it was planning to deliver a further £105m of savings over the coming year - but said it expects to be hit with an £80m restructuring charge to pay for the cost of moving from Fleet Street to new headquarters in London at Canary Wharf. "Improving customer relationships, more competitive products and continued strong cost discipline position us well for 2005," chief executive Tom Glocer said, adding the company was beginning "to look beyond recovery to growth".
llama3.2:1b: Reuters' revenues fell 11% to £2.89bn in 2004 due to currency weakness but beat profit forecasts by a 52%.
The company's debt decreased from £610m to £160m and it delivered further savings of £105m, with an expected restructuring charge of £80m for moving to new headquarters.
llama3.2:3b: Reuters reported a 11% drop in revenues to £2.89bn in 2004 due to dollar weakness, but beat profit forecasts with a 52% increase to £198m.
The company also slowed underlying revenue decline and cut debt to £160m.
It plans to deliver further £105m of savings, but expects an £80m restructuring charge.
gemma2:2b: Reuters' revenues decreased by 11% due to dollar weakness in 2004.
However, profits rose significantly (52%) and savings reached £234 million.
Despite revenue decline, Reuters slowed underlying revenue decline to 5.4%, reduced debt, and showed positive signs for the year ahead.
qwen2.5:0.5b: The media group Reuters' revenue fell 11% in 2004, mainly due to weak currencies.
The company's revenues decreased by £3.24bn from 2003's £3.89bn to £2.89bn during the same period.
In addition, the company reported a 52% rise in profits for 2004.
The company also announced it would save £220m over the next three years and plan to deliver an additional £105m of savings.
Reuters expects further improvement in 2005 with improved customer relationships, more competitive products, and continued cost discipline.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Reuters reported a 11% revenue decline in 2004 due to dollar weakness, but beat profit forecasts with an 83% rise and saved £234m.
The group maintained debt levels at £160m despite falling revenues.
It expects further improvement in Q2 and plans another £105m of savings.
qwen2.5:3b: Revenues at Reuters decreased by 11% in 2004 due to a weak dollar.
Despite this, the company reported a 52% increase in profits to £198m from £130m the previous year.
Reuters successfully achieved its savings target of £234m for 2004 and managed to stabilize revenue decline (from 10.2% in 2003) to 5.4%.
The company reduced its debt by half, from £610m to £160m.
Reuters also anticipated gradual improvement in second quarter sales, with plans for further savings of £105m over the next year.
However, it faces a £80m restructuring charge for moving headquarters to Canary Wharf.
CEO Tom Glocer stated that the company is now looking towards growth rather than recovery.
opencoder:1.5b: "Weak dollar hits Reuters" - during which the weak dollar contributed significantly to the decline in revenues, led to a significant increase in profits.
The group has managed to slow a decline in underlying revenues, followed by a cut in debt.
The news and financial data seller noted well that the year has started well with "further gradual improvement" in the second quarter of the year.
The company is anticipating "a further £105m of savings over the coming year - but plans to be hit with an £80m restructuring charge".
However, the group has been optimistic about growth and continues strong cost discipline.
smollm:1.7b: Reuters slipped 11% in 2004 due to a weak dollar.
Reuters also beat its profit forecast by 52%.
Reuters managed to slow a decline in underlying revenues and cut its debt back to £160m from £610m a year earlier.
The news and financial data seller said the year had begun well, adding it expected "further gradual improvement" in the second quarter of the year after good January sales.

It added it was planning to deliver a further £105m of savings over the coming year - but said it expects to be hit with an £80m restructuring charge to pay for the cost of moving from Fleet Street to new headquarters in London at Canary Wharf.

"Improving customer relationships, more competitive products and continued strong cost discipline position us well for 2005," chief executive Tom Glocer said, adding the company was beginning "to look beyond recovery to growth".
deepseek-r1:1.5b: The weak dollar affected Reuters's 2004 revenues, falling by 11% compared to 2003.
Profits were ahead of expectations with a 52% increase from £130m to £198m, and they reduced their savings target by £234m instead of the planned £220m under the Fast Forward plan.

Reuters expected further improvement in second quarter sales after strong January results and planned to cut £450m more aggressively, paying restructuring costs of £80m, before focusing on long-term growth.
tinyllama:1.1b: A media group called Reuter's reported a weak dollar hit its revenues during 2004, mainly due to the decline in the value of the US currency.
The company anticipates further improvements over the coming year, with an additional £105m cost expected as part of their turnaround plan.
Despite negative economic impacts, Reuter's remains optimistic about growth and continued strong profitability despite the slowdown.
tinydolphin:1.1b: Reuters reported a significant drop in revenues due to the weakening of its currency against major global currencies.
This affected both media revenue and overall group revenues as their sales slumped from £3.24 billion ($6.13 billion) in 2003 to £2.89 billion in 2004.
Despite this, Reuters maintained its profit forecasts and reported a 52% increase in profits for the year.
The company's savings plan aimed to save £220 million during the 12 months to December 2004.
However, it was unable to meet this target as they faced increasing overhead costs from its new headquarters and increased competition within the news industry.
Despite these challenges, Reuters continued to improve customer relationships, launch more competitive products, and anticipate growth in 2005.
phi:2.7b: Reuters reported that while its revenues declined 11% due to a weak dollar in 2004, the group remained optimistic about growth.
The company beat profit and savings targets, slowed a decline in underlying revenues, and planned to deliver more cost-cutting measures for the coming year.
However, it expected to face an $80 million restructuring charge from moving from Fleet Street to new headquarters at Canary Wharf.
Despite this setback, Reuters believed it was poised for recovery and growth in the future.
orca-mini:3b: Reuters reported a 11% decrease in revenues during 2004 due to the weak dollar, but managed to slow its decline in underlying revenues to 5.4%, cut debt back to £160m from £610m a year earlier, and plans to deliver further £105m of savings over the coming year.
However, it expects to be hit with an £80m restructuring charge for moving from Fleet Street to new headquarters in London at Canary Wharf and will begin charging customers for its services.
Despite these challenges, CEO Tom Glocer said the company was beginning to look beyond recovery to growth.
hermes3:3b: Reuters reports 11% drop in revenues to $2.89B in 2004 due to weak dollar, while beating profit forecasts with 52% rise to £198m and meeting savings target of £234m.
stablelm-zephyr:3b: In 2004, Reuters' revenues declined by 11% due to the weak dollar, though the company remained optimistic about future growth.
It exceeded profit forecasts, posting a 52% increase in profits to £198m from the previous year's £130m.
Under its Fast Forward plan, Reuters achieved savings of £234m and slowed the decline in underlying revenues to 5.4% from 10.2% in 2003.
The company projected further savings of £105m over the coming year, but expects an £80m restructuring charge for moving to new headquarters in London.
stablelm2:1.6b: Reuters experienced a 4% slip in revenues due to the weak dollar, with a 9% drop from £3.5bn ($6.2bn) to £2.5bn in Q4.
Despite this, the company beat profit forecasts and delivered £1m of cuts under its three-year Fast Forward plan.
They managed to slow a decline in underlying revenues, cut debt back to £1m from £1m a year earlier, and improved customer relationships.
For Q5, they expect further gradual improvement with plans for a further £1m of savings.
granite3.1-dense:2b: Reuters, a media group, reported a 11% decrease in annual revenues from £3.24 billion in 2003 to £2.89 billion in 2004, primarily due to the weak U.S. dollar's impact on its earnings.
Despite this revenue decline, Reuters exceeded profit forecasts with a 52% rise in profits to £198 million, outperforming its savings target by delivering £234 million in cost reductions.
The company under its Fast Forward plan had initially sought to save £220 million for the year ending December 31, 2004.
Reuters managed to slow the decline in underlying revenues from 10.2% in 2003 to 5.4% and reduced its debt from £610 million to £160 million.
The firm began 2005 with promising sales, anticipating further gradual improvement in the second quarter.
For the upcoming year, Reuters aims to save an additional £105 million, but expects an £80 million restructuring charge for moving its headquarters from Fleet Street to Canary Wharf.
Chief Executive Tom Glocer expressed optimism about 2005, attributing the company's resilience to enhanced customer relationships, competitive products, and stringent cost discipline.
He signaled that Reuters was shifting its focus from recovery to growth.
chatgpt-4o-latest: Reuters' revenues fell 11% in 2004 due to a weak dollar, dropping from £3.24bn to £2.89bn.
Despite this, profits rose 52% to £198m, exceeding forecasts.
The company surpassed its cost-cutting target, saving £234m under its Fast Forward plan.
It also reduced its debt from £610m to £160m and slowed the decline in underlying revenues.
Reuters reported strong January sales and expected gradual improvement in the second quarter.
It planned £105m in further savings but anticipated an £80m restructuring charge for relocating to Canary Wharf.
CEO Tom Glocer expressed confidence in future growth beyond recovery.
